linkTarget.anchoringText: Jabal Hfit is shown in Fig.1, looking from east to west. The outrop is some 29 km long and 5 km wide. Starti graphically, the exposure provides access to the Rus Formation along its core and the Dammam and Asmari Formations along its flanks (see Fig. 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Photograph of Jabal Hafit looking from East to West. The foreground is an oasis formed from a spring emanating from the feature. The stratigraphy in plan view is shown in Fig. 2.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Photograph of Jabal Hafit looking from East to West. The foreground is an oasis formed from a spring emanating from the feature. The stratigraphy in plan view is shown in Fig. 2.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Jabal Hfit is shown in Fig.1, looking from east to west. The outrop is some 29 km long and 5 km wide. Starti graphically, the exposure provides access to the Rus Formation along its core and the Dammam and Asmari Formations along its flanks (see Fig. 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Primary stratigraphy exposed in Jabal Hafit (Abdelghany, 2002 ). The central heights of the outcrop are occupied by the Rus Formation and is flanked left and right (West and East) by Dammam Formation and the East Asmari Formation on both flanks.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Primary stratigraphy exposed in Jabal Hafit (Abdelghany, 2002 ). The central heights of the outcrop are occupied by the Rus Formation and is flanked left and right (West and East) by Dammam Formation and the East Asmari Formation on both flanks.

linkTarget.bib:
Abdelghany, 2002
O. Abdelghany , 2002, Biostratigraphy (Turborotalia cunialensis/Cribrohantkenina inflata Concurrent-Range Zone, P16) of the Late Eocene Dammam Formation, west of the Northern Oman Mountains . Micropaleontology
48, 209 221 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: Nevertherless, the range of porosties and permeabilities shown in Fig. 3 are a clear example of the variability to be expected in carbonate reservoirs. There is over two orders of magnitude range in permeability and only a factor of ten in porosity, with seemingly little correlation between the two in linear or semi-log space.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Compilation of porosity and permeability data reported for carbonate samples from the Saudi Arabian outcrop of the Rus Formation ( Abdullatif, 2010 ) and the UAE core and outcrop samples of the Asmari Formation (Al-Attar (2010) . Plot on the right shows the same data in a semi-log plot.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Compilation of porosity and permeability data reported for carbonate samples from the Saudi Arabian outcrop of the Rus Formation ( Abdullatif, 2010 ) and the UAE core and outcrop samples of the Asmari Formation (Al-Attar (2010) . Plot on the right shows the same data in a semi-log plot.

linkTarget.bib:
Abdullaltif, 2010
O. Abdullaltif , 2010, Geomechanical properties and rock mass quality of the carbonate Rus Formation, Dammam Dome, Saudi Arabia, Arabian J. Sci. and Eng. , 35 , 2A , 173 197 .

Al-Attar, 2010
H. H. Al-Attar , 2010, Experimental study of spontaneous capillary imbibition in selected carbonates , J. Petrol. Science and Engineering , 70, 320 326 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: Mineralogy was determined through transmission infrared spectroscopy the details of this technique are given in Sondergeld and Rai (1993) and Ballard (2007). Noteworthy in the mineralogy is the lack of any secondray minerals, such as clays, in particular (see Fig. 4). Furthermore, the samples are dominately calcite with little to no dolomite (see Fig. 5, right). Dolomitization does, in a subtantive way, change petrophysical properties (Abdullatif, 2010).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Compositional bar graph showing the FTIR mineralogy of samples from the Jabal Hafit are dominated by carbonates. The total carbonate, i.e., (calcite+dolomite +aragonite+siderite) dominates. There are minor amounts of clay throughout the system.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Compositional bar graph showing the FTIR mineralogy of samples from the Jabal Hafit are dominated by carbonates. The total carbonate, i.e., (calcite+dolomite +aragonite+siderite) dominates. There are minor amounts of clay throughout the system.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Mineralogy was determined through transmission infrared spectroscopy the details of this technique are given in Sondergeld and Rai (1993) and Ballard (2007). Noteworthy in the mineralogy is the lack of any secondray minerals, such as clays, in particular (see Fig. 4). Furthermore, the samples are dominately calcite with little to no dolomite (see Fig. 5, right). Dolomitization does, in a subtantive way, change petrophysical properties (Abdullatif, 2010).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Ternary diagrams with the diagram on the left showing the quartz, carbonate and clay content of the Asmari(green), Dammam (blue) and Rus (red) outcrop samples from Jabal Hafit. The system is dominately carbonate as also indicated in Fig. 4. The right ternary plot breaks out the carbonates, i.e., calacite, dolomite and siderite. The system is dominated by calcite with little dolomitization evident.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Ternary diagrams with the diagram on the left showing the quartz, carbonate and clay content of the Asmari(green), Dammam (blue) and Rus (red) outcrop samples from Jabal Hafit. The system is dominately carbonate as also indicated in Fig. 4. The right ternary plot breaks out the carbonates, i.e., calacite, dolomite and siderite. The system is dominated by calcite with little dolomitization evident.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Backscattered SEM images (Fig. 6) shown below capture the typical microstructure observed in the Rus, Asmari and Dammam Formations. To a large extent, these samples are crack free and are dominated by equant pores. This is consistent with the linear pressure behavior observed in the majority of porosity and permeability measurements. Composition varies, i.e. the Asmari samples have dolomitic crystallization within existing pores which affects density, porosity and permeability.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Backscattered SEM images of the Rus Formation (upper left), the Asmari Formation (upper right) and the Dammam Formation (lower left) at roughly the same magnifications. There is no evidence of cracks in these samples. The euhedral crystals seen in the Asmari sample (lower right) are dolomite, while the solution textures in the Rus dominate. In all Formations the pore space appears fairly equant.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Backscattered SEM images of the Rus Formation (upper left), the Asmari Formation (upper right) and the Dammam Formation (lower left) at roughly the same magnifications. There is no evidence of cracks in these samples. The euhedral crystals seen in the Asmari sample (lower right) are dolomite, while the solution textures in the Rus dominate. In all Formations the pore space appears fairly equant.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Backscattered SEM images of the Rus Formation
The euhedral crystals seen in the Asmari sample

linkTarget.anchoringText: Helium porosities were measured on 72 samples as a function of pressure (see Fig. 7); the porosity distributions are plotted by Formation in Fig. 7. Porosities were also derived from NMR and MICP measurements. We used the porosity pressure dependence to measure pore volume compressibility which showed high compressibility at low porosity, probably due to cracks, but almost a constant low value above 3% porosity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Porosity distribution for the sampled Formations. While there is a greater representation of the Dammam Formation, the range in porosities is less than that of the Asmari or Rus Formations.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Porosity distribution for the sampled Formations. While there is a greater representation of the Dammam Formation, the range in porosities is less than that of the Asmari or Rus Formations.

linkTarget.anchoringText: NMR measured porosities on pressure saturated samples and helium porosities are compared in Fig. 8. The results are shown in Fig. 8 along with data published by Straley et al. (1994) for carbonates. The agreement between the two is better at lower porosities, with the NMR porosity being less than the helium values at higher porosities. The best fitting line shows a high correlation coefficient. The Straley et al. (1994) data fall systematically above the 1:1 line suggesting a bulk shift in mineralogy.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Helium porosity measurements (n=72) compared to the NMR porosities measured on dodecane saturated samples. UAE samples are blue diamond and Straley et al., (1994) carbonates (n=71) are in green circles. The dashed line is a 1:1 line and the parallel dotted lines are ±1 % lines. UAE data at lower porosities fall nicely on the 1:1 but at higher porosities the NMR values are lower. The Straley et al., (1994) values are systematically above the 1:1 line.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Helium porosity measurements (n=72) compared to the NMR porosities measured on dodecane saturated samples. UAE samples are blue diamond and Straley et al., (1994) carbonates (n=71) are in green circles. The dashed line is a 1:1 line and the parallel dotted lines are ±1 % lines. UAE data at lower porosities fall nicely on the 1:1 but at higher porosities the NMR values are lower. The Straley et al., (1994) values are systematically above the 1:1 line.

linkTarget.bib:
Straley et al., 1994
C. Straley , D. Rossini , H. Vinegar , P. Tutunjian and C. Moriss , 1994, Core analyis by low field NMR , SCA-9404 , 43 56 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 9, we compare the porosities dervived from the MICP measurements, ϕHg, made at 60,000 psi injection pressures (red circles) with ϕHe and ϕNMR. While the ϕHg values fall along the trend line established for the ϕHe and ϕNMR, the observed scatter is considerably larger and the corresponding correlation coefficient is lower by ~12%.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Helium porosity measurements (blue diamonds) (n=72) compared to the NMR porosities measured on dodecane saturated samples and porosities derived from MICP (red circles), mercury injection, at 60,000 psi (n=25). Note that while agreement among the three methods is very good, the NMR produces superior agreement.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Helium porosity measurements (blue diamonds) (n=72) compared to the NMR porosities measured on dodecane saturated samples and porosities derived from MICP (red circles), mercury injection, at 60,000 psi (n=25). Note that while agreement among the three methods is very good, the NMR produces superior agreement.

linkTarget.anchoringText: For straight capillary tubes, the Kozeny equation offers a simple correlation between permeability and porosity. We measured porosities and permeabilities as a function of confining pressure and report the results at 1500 psi for the Klinkenberg permeabilities in Fig. 10. In general, there is a strong exponential dependence of permeability on porosity with the Asmari and Rus Formations fitting the trend better than the Dammam Formation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: A plot of measured permeabilities and porosities for the UAE carbonate samples. Symbols and colors indicate the Formations: blue diamonds (Rus), red squares (Dammam) and green triangles (Asmari). The samples from the Dammam Formation show the most scatter. The Asmari and Rus samples fall very nicely on the fitted line, indicating a better probability for predicting permeability from porosity in these Formations.

formatted-caption.caption-text: A plot of measured permeabilities and porosities for the UAE carbonate samples. Symbols and colors indicate the Formations: blue diamonds (Rus), red squares (Dammam) and green triangles (Asmari). The samples from the Dammam Formation show the most scatter. The Asmari and Rus samples fall very nicely on the fitted line, indicating a better probability for predicting permeability from porosity in these Formations.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Fig. 11 the blue diamonds represent flow zone 1 with a flow zone indicator of 9.5 μm and the red triangles represent flow unit 2 having a flow zone indicator index of 14.8 μm.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Based on the RQI index we can separate the samples into two distinct flow zone as indicated in the plot.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Based on the RQI index we can separate the samples into two distinct flow zone as indicated in the plot.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Measured T2 log weighted geometric mean values for the Jabal Hafit outcrop samples. The preponderance of values is small, i.e. below 80 ms, suggesting smaller pore bodies.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Measured T2 log weighted geometric mean values for the Jabal Hafit outcrop samples. The preponderance of values is small, i.e. below 80 ms, suggesting smaller pore bodies.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The SDR equation requires log T2 geometric mean and porosity. The measured geometric means are presented in Fig. 13. The Coates-Timur requires either an assumption of a T2 cutoff—typically 100 ms for carbonate—or measured values; we used both. We performed a series of desaturation experiments by centrifuging the samples to an equivalent pressure of 100 psi for 12 hours to establish meaningful T2 cutoff values.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Histogram of measured T2 log weighted geometric mean for the Jabal Hafit outcrop samples. The preponderance of values is small, i.e. below 80 ms.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Histogram of measured T2 log weighted geometric mean for the Jabal Hafit outcrop samples. The preponderance of values is small, i.e. below 80 ms.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Coates-Timur permeabilities using the generic value for C=10 (green triangles). The calibrated data (blue diamonds) used a value of C=12.9 and the measured T2 cutoff values. There is a marginal improvement after calibration against core, i.e., R2 increases from 0.62 to 0.71. The overall correlation coefficient is still below the best achieved with the SDR permeability estimation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Coates-Timur permeabilities using the generic value for C=10 (green triangles). The calibrated data (blue diamonds) used a value of C=12.9 and the measured T2 cutoff values. There is a marginal improvement after calibration against core, i.e., R2 increases from 0.62 to 0.71. The overall correlation coefficient is still below the best achieved with the SDR permeability estimation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The calibrated SDR permeability estimate appears superior to the generic SDR using standard constant values (see Fig. 15) and substantially better than either the calibrated or uncalibrated Coates-Timur estimate for these carbonate samples. Logan et al., (1998) made a similar observation in their carbonate study. They then forced the Coates-Timur permeabilities to match the SDR values to estimate T2 cutoffs from field data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: SDR estimated permeabilities compared to the measured Klinkenberg corrected core permeabilities at 1500 psi. The calibrated data (blue diamond) used a derived value of a=0.412. The uncalibrated used a value of a=1.6. The SDR permeability estimates after core calibration result in a superior correlation coefficient than the Coates-Timur estimates.

formatted-caption.caption-text: SDR estimated permeabilities compared to the measured Klinkenberg corrected core permeabilities at 1500 psi. The calibrated data (blue diamond) used a derived value of a=0.412. The uncalibrated used a value of a=1.6. The SDR permeability estimates after core calibration result in a superior correlation coefficient than the Coates-Timur estimates.
